Argentina and U.S. sign a major trade deal to slash tariffs, boost political alliancetoggle caption Evan Vucci/APBUENOS AIRES, Argentina — Argentina and the United States agreed Thursday to ease restrictions on each other's goods in an expansive trade deal that boosts a drive by President Javier Milei to open up Argentina's protectionist economy and a push by the Trump administration to reduce food prices for Americans.
A trade deal between ideological alliesOn Thursday Argentine Foreign Minister Pablo Quirno and U.S. Trade Representative Jamieson Greer said they signed the trade and investment agreement in Washington.
After imposing sweeping tariffs on its trading partners, the Trump administration changed its tune last November in announcing framework deals with four Latin American countries, including Argentina.

Washington, for its part, will eliminate reciprocal tariffs on 1,675 Argentine products, Argentina's Foreign Ministry said, increasing government export revenue by over $1 billion.

Gurman says Apple is planning to pitch the iPhone 17e aggressively in emerging markets and to enterprises.

article.title: Britain to invest up to $1.4 billion in community energy projects
article.summary:
LONDON, Feb 9 (Reuters) - Britain will invest up to 1 billion pounds ($1.4 billion) in community ​energy projects, such as installing solar panels on ‌libraries and other public buildings, to help meet climate targets and ‌cut local energy costs, it said on Tuesday.
The Local Power Plan, ‌launched on Monday, aims to support locally owned clean energy projects across community buildings ‍and public sites.
It will be backed by Great British Energy, the government's publicly owned energy company, with the funding ​part of the 8.3 billion pounds committed to ‌GBE over the current Parliament.
Energy Secretary Ed Miliband said the initiative would allow communities to own and control clean energy generation, ensuring profits flow into local areas rather than to large energy companies.
The funding will be distributed through grants and loans to community energy ⁠groups and local authorities, with schemes launching later this year, ‌the government said.

article.summary:
Donald Trump’s border tsar warned months ago that the administration’s aggressive and sweeping immigration crackdown risked losing public support.
In a June 16 interview for NBC, published for the first time on Monday, Mr Homan said: “I think the vast majority of the American people think criminal illegal aliens need to leave.
In the face of cross-party and nationwide outcry following the deaths of Renee Good and Alex Pretti, both 37, Mr Trump pledged to “de-escalate”.
He replaced Mr Bovino, the hardline “commander at large” of Border Control who had been leading the immigration operation in the city, with Mr Homan to diffuse the tensions and scale back its most aggressive tactics.
There has been a 2,450 per cent increase in the number of people with no criminal record being held in ICE detention, according to a new report by the American Immigration Council.

article.title: Number of homeless refugees in England soars, BBC has found
article.summary:
Once an asylum seeker is given refugee status they have 28 days to move out of government-funded accommodation - usually a house in multiple occupation (HMO) or a hotel - and find their own housing.
At the same time, they must find work or, if necessary, apply for universal credit.

article.title: Leadership changes in Minnesota follow tensions among agencies over immigration enforcement tactics
article.summary:
In Congress, the Department of Homeland Security is increasingly under attack by Democrats who want to rein in immigration enforcement.
“In targeted enforcement operations, we go out there.
The Border Patrol does.”The Border Patrol's high-profile raids, including a helicopter landing on the roof of a Chicago apartment building that involved agents rappelling down, rankled ICE officials.
Many were replaced by current or retired officials from CBP, the Border Patrol's parent agency.
Homan's arrival in Minnesota and his emphasis on “targeted enforcement” mark a subtle but unmistakable shift, at least in tone.

article.title: US moves to deport 5-year-old detained in Minnesota
article.summary:
By Jasper WardWASHINGTON, Feb 6 (Reuters) - The U.S. Department of Homeland Security said on Friday it is seeking to deport ​a 5-year-old Ecuadorean boy who was detained in Minnesota last month.
"These are regular removal proceedings," ⁠department spokesperson Tricia McLaughlin ‌said, adding, "This is standard procedure and there is nothing retaliatory about enforcing the nation’s immigration laws."
Lawyers for Liam and ‍the Department of Justice did not immediately respond to requests for comments.
The Trump administration defended the move, with the Department of Homeland Security accusing Conejo Arias of being in the U.S. illegally, without providing additional details.
Advertisement AdvertisementProtests have ⁠erupted across Minnesota in opposition to the deployment of immigration agents, who have fatally ‌shot two U.S. citizens in the state.

article.title: Minneapolis now has daily deportation flights. One man has been documenting them
article.summary:
Federally chartered deportation flights on ICE Air, as the Department of Homeland Security calls it , aren't new.
But in Trump's second term, their frequency and scope has essentially doubled, according to ICE Flight Monitor, an advocacy initiative that keeps watch.
toggle caption Jaida Grey Eagle"It's just happening in the background," says Benson, motioning to the rest of the airport.
But in recent months, he's started tracking these ICE flights in and out of Minneapolis, counting the people loaded on as they are forced to leave the state.
toggle caption Jaida Grey EagleHe says sometimes the weight of what he's witnessing each day catches up with him.

article.title: ICE protester speaks out after White House shared fake arrest image
article.summary:
US civil rights lawyer and activist Nekima Levy Armstrong says she was "disgusted" after the White House posted an image of her arrest which was edited to show her in tears.
She was detained for organising a protest against Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) in a Minnesota church last month.
BBC Verify's Jake Horton spoke to Levy Armstrong about the manipulated image and the backlash she has faced.
Produced by Tom Joyner.
Graphics by Mark Edwards.

article.title: Judge orders 3 families returned to US after finding agents used 'lies' to deport them
article.summary:
Judge orders 3 families returned to US after finding agents used 'lies' to deport themIn this Aug. 26, 2011, file photo, the Homeland Security logo is seen shortly before a press conference at FEMA headquarters in Washington, D.C.
In this Aug. 26, 2011, file photo, the Homeland Security logo is seen shortly before a press conference at FEMA headquarters in Washington, D.C.
In this Aug. 26, 2011, file photo, the Homeland Security logo is seen shortly before a press conference at FEMA headquarters in Washington, D.C.
In the eight-page ruling, Judge Sabraw found that the government's removal of the families rendered the protections of the settlement "illusory."
A spokesperson with the Department of Homeland Security did not immediately respond to a request for comment from ABC News.

article.title: Court records: Chicago immigration raid was about squatters, not Venezuelan gangs
article.summary:
Court records: Chicago immigration raid was about squatters, not Venezuelan gangstoggle caption Sergio Martínez-Beltrán/NPRNewly revealed arrest records show that a high-profile immigration raid on a South Shore Chicago apartment building last year that became a symbol of President Trump's harsh immigration tactics actually targeted squatters, not Venezuelan gang members.
On multiple occasions, the Trump administration has said the building was frequented by members of Tren de Aragua, a Venezuelan gang.
Sponsor MessageBut arrest records for two of the men show the government's stated reason for the raid was to take out squatters, not gang members.
"They have no legal authority to be addressing purported squatters; that is not within the purview of the federal government."
NPR went inside the building days after the raid and found it dilapidated, with graffiti on walls and doors.

article.title: Ukrainian shelling causes 'serious damage' in Russia's Belgorod, governor says
article.summary:
Feb 6 (Reuters) - Nighttime shelling by Ukraine inflicted "serious damage" in the Russian city of Belgorod, near the border, the region's governor said ​early on Friday.
Advertisement Advertisement"The enemy has shelled the civilian city of Belgorod.
In his morning address, Gladkov said the works to restore electric power supply continue.
"As of today, we have not ‍been able to fully ⁠restore electricity supply in Belgorod," he said.
Advertisement AdvertisementUkrainian forces have regularly attacked Belgorod and nearby parts of the region since Russia's February 2022 invasion ⁠of its smaller neighbour.

article.title: ‘Nothing retaliatory’: US seeks deportation of 5-year-old Liam Conejo Ramos
article.summary:
Lawyers for the Ecuadorian asylum seeker have speculated the Trump administration is seeking ‘retaliatory’ actions.
The United States Department of Homeland Security (DHS) has revealed it will continue to seek the deportation of five-year-old Liam Conejo Ramos and his father Adrian Conejo Arias, after their recent return to Minnesota.
Photos went viral of Conejo Ramos standing in the snow, dressed in floppy blue bunny ears, with an immigration agent grabbing onto his Spiderman backpack.
The detention of Conejo Ramos and his father had been among the high-profile flashpoints during the crackdown.
Conejo Ramos and his father arrived in the US from Ecuador.

article.title: State Department will delete X posts from before Trump returned to office
article.summary:
State Department will delete X posts from before Trump returned to officetoggle caption Anna Moneymaker/Getty ImagesThe State Department is removing all posts on its public accounts on the social media platform X made before President Trump returned to office on Jan. 20, 2025.
The posts will be internally archived but will no longer be on public view, the State Department confirmed to NPR.
The removal of State Department X posts from public view appears to be less about ideological differences with past statements and more about control of future messaging.
Some current and former State Department employees as well as academics worry that it will make the historical record of the government's communications and actions harder to trace.
The State Department also has publicly available archived versions of its website under previous administrations dating back to President Bill Clinton.

article.title: Lavrov Slams French Diplomacy as "Pathetic" After Macron Adviser's Moscow Visit
article.summary:
The boys dig into some of the most disappointing Designated Player signings in MLS history, from Rafa Márquez’s chaos years to the underwhelming impacts of Olivier Giroud, Xherdan Shaqiri, and Lorenzo Insigne.
Then it’s off to the Premier League, reacting to Liverpool’s heated loss to Manchester City — was the red card fair, and what does City’s win mean for Arsenal as the title race tightens?
Finally, the crew breaks down Mauricio Pochettino telling Timothy Weah to “keep quiet” about World Cup ticket prices and what that moment says about power, pressure, and transparency in the modern game.

article.title: Universities told to report foreign interference on campus to MI5
article.summary: Meawhile, in November BBC News reported how a campaign of harassment and intimidation took place at Sheffield Hallam University in an attempt to shut down an academic's research into allegations of forced labour among Uyghur Muslims in the Xinjiang region of China.

article.title: Foreign Office to review Mandelson's US ambassador pay-off
article.summary:
However, he is believed to have been given an exit payment equivalent to three months' salary according to the Times.
While his salary as US ambassador has not been disclosed, the post typically has a salary of £155,000-£159,999.
This would put a three months' pay-out at around £40,000.

article.title: Trump’s America First doctrine is remaking global diplomacy
article.summary:
His political trajectory and election as President of the United States were unprecedented.
Critics dismiss the Trump Doctrine as nothing more than a chaotic combination of isolationism, dismantlement of multilateralism, and imperialism.
At its core, the Trump Doctrine rests on two strategic pillars designed to secure peace through strength and prosperity through leverage.
AdvertisementIt is essential to consider the Trump Administration’s global foreign policy achievements and objectives through a broad lens, recognising them as part of a deliberate and coherent strategic doctrine.
Both Presidents put America First and carried a big stick, prioritising national power as the foundation of global influence and stability.

article.title: Europe set to treble sovereign cloud investment
article.summary:
Worldwide sovereign cloud spending is forecast to hit $80 billion in 2026, up 35.6 percent from 2025.
Speaking to The Register, Rene Buest, Gartner senior director analyst, agreed geopolitics was a factor in European sovereign cloud decisions since January last year.
A broader issue of strategic or economic sovereignty was influencing investment decisions to make local and regional cloud providers more competitive.
"But the AWS European Sovereign Cloud GmbH is a 100 percent subsidiary of Amazon Inc.
It claimed:"These dedicated European subsidiaries maintain direct management and control over the AWS European Sovereign Cloud infrastructure and operations, and are led by EU citizens who are obligated to abide by European laws and to act in the best interest of the AWS European Sovereign Cloud."

article.title: Saudi Arabia denounces ‘foreign interference’ in Sudan after RSF attacks
article.summary:
In a statement on Saturday, the Saudi Ministry of Foreign Affairs condemned “foreign interference” by “some parties” in Sudan, including the “continued influx of illegal weapons, mercenaries and foreign fighters” for the continuation of the nearly three-year-old war.
The Saudi Ministry of Foreign Affairs said on Saturday the deadly RSF attacks “are completely unjustifiable and constitute flagrant violations of all humanitarian norms and relevant international agreements”.
Separately, Saudi Arabia has also accused the UAE of backing the separatist Southern Transitional Council (STC) in Yemen.
The offensive resulted in a split in Yemen’s internationally-backed government, and prompted Saudi Arabia to launch deadly raids targeting the STC.
The UAE pulled out its troops from Yemen following the Saudi allegation, saying it supports Saudi Arabia’s security.

article.title: Iran and US to reopen nuclear talks in Oman after weeks of tension
article.summary:
LONDON -- Negotiating teams from the United States and Iran are expected to meet on Friday in Oman, marking a reopening of nuclear talks following weeks of tensions and threats, as leaders in Tehran oversaw a deadly crackdown on widespread protests.
Omani Foreign Ministry via AFP via Getty ImagesThe talks, which were expected to begin at 10 a.m. local time, followed weeks of escalating tension between the U.S. and Iran, fueled in part by massive protests that have roiled Iran.
Iran's foreign minister met with his Omani counterpart in Muscat on Feb. 6, ahead of Oman-mediated talks with the United States on the Islamic republic's nuclear program.
The Iranian foreign minister responded by saying the country's military had "their fingers on the trigger."
Members of the Trump administration last held a series of nuclear talks with Iran in April and May 2025 in Oman.

article.title: Israel’s Gaza genocide risks global order, leaders warn at Al Jazeera Forum
article.summary:
Israel’s war on Gaza and ‘expansionist’ actions beyond are reshaping global politics and threatening stability outside the region, forum hears in Doha.
Israel’s genocide against Palestinians in Gaza and its geopolitical fallout reverberating across the Middle East and beyond have dominated the 17th Al Jazeera Forum in Doha.
Israeli threat to the Red SeaSomali President Hassan Sheikh Mohamud, also speaking at the forum, warned that Israel’s Gaza war and escalating tensions in the Red Sea are unfolding alongside a broader breakdown in the international system.
Placing the conflict within a wider geopolitical context, Mohamud warned that the foundations of global governance are weakening.
“Key among the global concerns is the weakening of the established rules based on international order.

article.title: Japan's Takaichi to pursue conservative agenda after election landslide
article.summary:
Japan's Takaichi to pursue conservative agenda after election landslidetoggle caption Keisuke Hosojima/Kyodo News/APSEOUL — Japan's first female Prime Minister, Sanae Takaichi, brought the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) its biggest electoral victory in its 71-year history, fueling her ambitions to pursue to a political agenda which she herself says could "split public opinion."
Charismatic Japanese leaders, including Takaichi's mentor former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, have helped the LDP stage comebacks before.
Questions and criticisms remain about how Takaichi will pay for these priorities, given that Japan's government debt is more than 200% of GDP.
Takaichi also restated at her press conference her intention to revise Japan's National Defense Strategy and related documents.
"This year marks 10 years since Prime Minister Shinzo Abe advocated a free and open Indo-Pacific," Takaichi told the press conference.

article.title: China critic and former media tycoon Jimmy Lai sentenced to 20 years in Hong Kong
article.summary:
China critic and former media tycoon Jimmy Lai sentenced to 20 years in Hong Kongtoggle caption Vincent Yu/APHONG KONG — Jimmy Lai, the pro-democracy former Hong Kong media tycoon and a fierce critic of Beijing, was sentenced on Monday to 20 years in prison in the longest punishment given so far under a China-imposed national security law that has virtually silenced the city's dissent.
"It signifies the total destruction of the Hong Kong legal system and the end of justice," he said.
Hong Kong leader John Lee said Lai's sentence demonstrated the rule of law, citing his serious crimes.
Hong Kong ranked 140th out of 180 territories in the press-freedom index compiled by media freedom organization Reporters Without Borders in 2025, far from its 18th place in 2002.
"Obviously, he has done nothing good for Hong Kong that could serve as a basis for his mitigation," he told reporters.

article.title: Iran-US talks in Muscat bought time, not a deal
article.summary:
The first round of Iran-US talks in Muscat produced no breakthrough.
When Iranian and American negotiators concluded several hours of talks in Muscat on February 6, publicly, neither side signalled any shift from its opening position.
Diplomacy conducted under military escortThe most striking feature of the Muscat round was not what was said, but who sat in the room.
Consider the sequence of events surrounding the Muscat round itself.
The Muscat talks did not fail.

article.title: South Korea: Official expelled from party for remark on 'importing' foreign women
article.summary: The Vietnamese Embassy in Seoul had condemned Kim's remarks, saying in a statement on Facebook that his words were "not simply a matter of expression but a matter of values and attitudes towards migrant women and minority groups".

article.title: Russia says man suspected of shooting top general has been flown to Moscow from Dubai
article.summary:
His wife told a Russian war blogger on Sunday that Alexeyev ‌had regained consciousness and was able to talk.
Russia said Ukraine was behind the shooting but Kyiv has denied involvement.
Russian media showed masked FSB officers escorting a blindfolded ⁠man from a small jet in Russia in the ‌dark.
One, Viktor Vasin, was detained in Moscow, while another, Zinaida Serebritskaya, escaped to Ukraine, Russian investigators said.
'SERIOUS BLOW'The GRU, like the FSB, is a vast and powerful Russian intelligence agency that includes sleeper agents abroad, special forces units and advanced cyber capabilities.
